extraction_metadata.article_title: Business model innovation in mobile apps market: Exploring the new subscription plans with a behavioral reasoning perspective

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Subscription-based business model - A business model where consumers periodically pay a fee to access a catalogue of services (such as mobile apps), instead of paying for each service individually
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'subscription-based business model (Wang et al., 2005) where consumers periodically pay a fee to access a product/service' | Page 1: 'These subscription-based plans ask users to pay a fee to get access to a catalogue of services (such as movies, songs, books), instead of asking them to pay for each of them one by one' | Page 2: 'These new subscription-based catalogues can be interpreted as BMI'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_value: subscription plans
subscription-based plans
new subscription-based business models
subscription-based catalogues
fixed-price plan
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'new subscription-based business models designed to give users access to a catalogue of smartphone apps' | Page 2: 'These new subscription-based catalogues can be interpreted as BMI' | Page 12: 'subscribe a fixed-price plan to get access to a smoother user experience'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Mobile apps – i.e. software for mobile devices – have had a disruptive impact on the world economy' | Page 1: 'These subscription based business models have only been recently introduced in the mobile applications market'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the target customer type of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'we study the consumer's perception of the new subscription-based business models' | Page 1: 'we employ a PLS-SEM approach to study the data gathered on a sample of 294 mobile apps users in Italy'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the typical size of offering companies that adopt this software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'These plans are a BMI from the perspective of the companies creating the stores, such as Google and Apple' | Page 1: 'more than 2 million apps in the Google's Play store and 1.83 million apps in Apple's AppStore in 2019'

extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'we employ a PLS-SEM approach to study the data gathered on a sample of 294 mobile apps users in Italy' | Page 4: 'We have tested our research model on a sample of Italian mobile users'

extracted_data.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Mobile app users with varying levels of app usage (non-experts, users, enthusiast users)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'we engaged 18 people (nine males and nine females) of different age groups selected to have user in three categories non-experts (those with fewer than 40 apps installed on their phones), users (with 40 to 80 apps on their phones), and enthusiast users (more than 80 apps installed on their phones)'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value: App developers | Create and provide apps | Receive payment from catalogue management company | Not specified | Catalogue management company (Google/Apple) | Manage app store and subscription plans | Pay developers based on downloads/usage | Provide platform to consumers | Consumers | Subscribe to access app catalogue | Pay subscription fee to catalogue management company | Download and use apps from developers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'Even in the App developer perspective they may be considered as a BMI asking them to redesign their apps to leverage the new way of getting revenue from the catalogue management company that usually pay them according to the number of times the specific apps gets downloaded and used' | Page 2: 'These plans are a BMI from the perspective of the companies creating the stores, such as Google and Apple'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Access to broader selection of apps
Opportunity to share subscription among devices
Better mobile experience without interruptions
Smoother user experience with no pauses
All apps for a global price with no in-app purchases
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'In the end, the focus groups identified as "reasons for" subscribing a plan to get access to mobile apps: to have access to a broader selection of apps ("I am free to try the apps I don't know"), to have the opportunity to share the same subscription among various devices, to have a better mobile experience (two different items: "I have a better user experience as there are no interruptions" and "I have a smoother user experience with no pauses"), and to get the opportunity to have all the apps for a global price, with no in-app purchases'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Perceived Control → Strongest predictor of adoption intention
Global Motives → Main predictor of behavioral intention
Value Compatibility → Influences reasons for and against adoption
Broad catalogue → Helps users choose freely without individual payments
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'our results for the General Motives, show that the strongest effect on the adoption intention is related to the Perceived Control' | Page 1: 'Global Motives are the main predictor of the consumers' behavioral intention' | Page 5: 'Looking at the influences of Values, we have a stronger effect on the context-specific motivations' | Page 12: 'managers should try to leverage these new subscription-based plans in their strategies engaging a broad set of app-developers in order to offer a broad catalogue to help users in choosing freely which ones they want to try without having to pay for each of them'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Mobile device ownership → Access to app catalogue
Internet connectivity → Download and use apps
App store presence → Distribution platform
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'Mobile apps – i.e. software for mobile devices' | Page 1: 'subscription-based business models designed to give users access to a catalogue of smartphone apps' | Page 1: 'more than 2 million apps in the Google's Play store and 1.83 million apps in Apple's AppStore'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Limited app catalogue → Some normally used apps may not be included
App removal risk → Apps may be excluded from catalogue later
Geographic availability → Plans not available in most countries
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'On the other side the elicited "reasons against" were linked: to the dimension of the App catalogue (two different items: "Some of the apps I normally use may be not included" - "I may access for free only a few apps") and to the risk of not being able to use the apps if they go out of the catalogue' | Page 12: 'As the subscription plans to get access to apps are still not available in most countries and in particular in the specific context of our research, Italy, they were still fairly new'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Limited app catalogue availability
Risk of app removal from catalogue
Geographic unavailability in most countries
Consumer resistance to new pricing model
Need for broad developer engagement
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Some of the apps I normally use may be not included' | Page 3: 'I may access for free only a few apps' | Page 3: 'the risk of not being able to use the apps if they go out of the catalogue' | Page 12: 'As the subscription plans to get access to apps are still not available in most countries' | Page 12: 'managers should try to leverage these new subscription-based plans in their strategies engaging a broad set of app-developers'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Broad developer engagement → Mitigates limited catalogue → Provides diverse app selection
Policies to ease user fears → Mitigates app removal concerns → Increases perceived control
Customized subscription plans → Mitigates user resistance → Better user experience
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 12: 'managers should try to leverage these new subscription-based plans in their strategies engaging a broad set of app-developers in order to offer a broad catalogue to help users in choosing freely which ones they want to try without having to pay for each of them and without having their experience interrupted by ads' | Page 12: 'The results hint that managers should implement policies to ease the users fear to be unable to access the apps they normally use as some of them may not be included in the catalogue or, they may be excluded at some later moment in time' | Page 12: 'These results will help mangers to design their strategies and increase the use of subscription-based plans more customized and useful for users' needs'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Sample size: 294; Unit: mobile app users; Period: study period; Method: PLS-SEM analysis; Source: Italian mobile users survey | R² values: Adoption Intention 0.920, Attitude 0.793, Perceived Control 0.729, Subjective Norms 0.684, Reasons For 0.515, Reasons Against 0.439; Unit: variance explained; Period: study period; Method: PLS-SEM; Source: structural model analysis | Market size: 935 billion USD; Unit: expected global market; Period: 2023; Method: Statista projection; Source: Statista 2019 | App count: 2 million (Google Play), 1.83 million (Apple AppStore); Unit: number of apps; Period: 2019; Method: store data; Source: store statistics | User base: 6.3 billion; Unit: users; Period: 2021; Method: EPRS data; Source: EPRS 2018
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'we employ a PLS-SEM approach to study the data gathered on a sample of 294 mobile apps users in Italy' | Page 5: 'For the Adoption Intention and the Attitude we have found an R2 higher than 0.75 (respectively 0.920 and 0.793)' | Page 1: 'an expected global market bigger than 935 billion U.S. dollars in 2023 (Statista, 2019)' | Page 1: 'more than 2 million apps in the Google's Play store and 1.83 million apps in Apple's AppStore in 2019' | Page 1: 'more than 6.3 billion users in 2021 (EPRS, 2018)'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the temporal period and maturity of the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'These subscription based business models have only been recently introduced in the mobile applications market' | Page 2: 'subscription-based plans to get access to a catalogue of mobile apps as they are fairly new and still narrowly diffused' | Page 12: 'As the subscription plans to get access to apps are still not available in most countries and in particular in the specific context of our research, Italy, they were still fairly new'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the type of evidence presented in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'we employ a PLS-SEM approach to study the data gathered on a sample of 294 mobile apps users in Italy' | Page 4: 'We collected the data with an anonymous online survey that we shared using both email and social networking sites'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_value: Google Play Pass → Example of existing subscription plan for mobile apps
Apple Arcade → Example of existing subscription plan for mobile apps
Google Play Store → Platform hosting subscription-based app catalogue
Apple AppStore → Platform hosting subscription-based app catalogue
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'The meeting was started presenting them the main characteristics of the existing subscription plans (Google Play Pass, and Apple Arcade)' | Page 1: 'more than 2 million apps in the Google's Play store and 1.83 million apps in Apple's AppStore in 2019'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Premium model → App is paid to install on mobile device
Freemium model → Users get app for free but pay for new features or service tiers
Advertising model → Display advertising within the app
In-App Purchases → Generate revenue through in-app transactions
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'the main business models are premium - i.e., when the app is paid in order to install it on the mobile device – and freemium – i.e., when users can get the app for free, but they have to pay to get new features or to access new tiers of service' | Page 1: 'Mobile Apps developers, also, may monetize their services (Scholz, 2017) displaying advertising within the app, or generating In-App Purchases'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Rapid spread expected → Based on success in other industries like music, videogames, and books
Potential disruptive impact → Similar to what happened in music and movies streaming services
Need for broader geographic availability → Currently limited to few countries
Economic significance → Expected to play relevant role in mobile app market growth
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 12: 'the recent introduction of the subscription-based business model could have disruptive impacts as it has already done in other industries (such as music and movies streaming services, or the videogames subscriptions plans)' | Page 12: 'it will be fundamental for companies and the main players of the ecosystem to support the rapid spread of these new plans and support their development' | Page 12: 'these new subscription-based plans could have a significant impact from an economic point of view and, therefore, play a relevant role in the growth and development of the mobile app market'
